JOHN, PEARL, RACHEL, RUBY, DURING WASHING

WALT, ICEY, MEMBERS OF COURTROOM AUDIENCE
CHILDREN STAND UP, LOOK TOWARDS PREACHER, AN
RACHEL AND CHILDREN OVER TWO POLICE CARS

THE THUMPING FISH IN BOTTOM OF BOAT
THE GIRLS, OVER RACHEL AND HARPER CHILDREN
JOHN'S HAND COMES TO REST BESIDE A HAIRBRUSH
JOHN'S HANDS PIN THE DOLL TOGETHER
CHILDREN AND SKIFF, OVER RABBITS IN GRASS
THE MOVING SKIFF, THROUGH DEW-JEWELED SPI

THE SKIFF, DRIFTING SHOT THROUGH RIVERSIDE

THE OUTSIDE, FEATURING EMPTY STUMP, RACHEL'S
AN OWL ON A BRANCH, LOOKING DOWN CLOSE SHOT
THE BACK OF JOHN'S HEAD, IMMOBILE

CLOCK AND HALL MIRROR, BEYOND DARK KITCHEN
A SHELF, FULL OF MARKET BASKETS, NEATLY COVE

dialogues.speaker: A DANCER
dialogues.text: She is hard at work, to music o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SEAT
dialogues.text: Among the members of the sad burlesque audience, he is in strong contrast: a sour and aggressive expression. Music  o.s. We MOVE IN fast to a HEAD CLOSE-UP.

dialogues.speaker: HAND
dialogues.text: Labeled H-A-T-E in tattoo across four knuckles, it grips flexes.

dialogues.speaker: HIS RIGHT HAND
dialogues.text: Before we see the lettering he slides it into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: His head slants; a cold smile; one eyelid flutters.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT HAND AND POCKET
dialogues.text: We hear the snapping open of a switch-blade knife and the point of the knife cuts through his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He seems to "listen" for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there are too many of them; you  can't kill a world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand descends firmly onto his shoulder. He glances up b him as we

dialogues.speaker: A STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: He bends down and speaks quietly next PREACHER'S ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You driving an Essex tourin'-car  with a Moundsville license?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry Powell, for the theft of that  touring car you will spend thirty  days in the Moundsville Penitentiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting Clerk) Preacher Harry Powell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car thief! Picked up where you  were! A man of God? (to Clerk) Harry Powell.

dialogues.speaker: MOUNDSVILLE PENITENTIARY
dialogues.text: A grim stone turretted faзade; an American flag idles at center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in the grass, a sentimental picture. JOHN is nin PEARL is five. They are working together on PEARL'S doll; PEARL is dressing her, while JOHN gets on a difficult sho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand still, Miss Jenny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across her) There! What's so hard about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He proudly exhibits the shod foot. They hear the sound of an auto engine o.s. They look o.s. and get up, PEARL dangling the doll.

dialogues.speaker: OVER THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: A Model-T Ford approaches at maximal speed on uneven dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John, happily) Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car careens towards us; then swings into the sideyard we PAN, and stops. They run towards their father fast; then JOHN looks puzzl and they stop short. BEN HARPER half-falls out of the far door, his shoulder b stained, his eyes wild. A hefty, simple man of thirty. He looks at them, dazed, across the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out shopping -- you're bleeding, Dad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this he comes around clear of the car with a revolver one hand and a bloody roll of banknotes in the other.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He screams. BEN slaps him with the back of the money hand leaving blood on JOHN'S cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL, and the house, are in BACKGROUND. PEARL just clutc her doll. During BEN'S next lines, JOHN touches his cheek and looks at the blood on his fingers and at the bloody m of which we FLASH-CUT an INSERT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing) Listen! This money here! We got to  hide it before they get me! There's  close to ten thousand dollars. (his eyes dart wildly) Under a rock in the smokehouse? Ah  no. Under the bricks in the grape  arbor? No, they'd dig for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden triumph) Why sure! That's the place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves forward and OUT and in his place we see two poli cars, small in distance, coming fast. We hear sirens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and OVER two STATE TROOPERS. They move at high speed,  with sirens. BEN and his CHILDREN, tiny in the distance,  dilate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (driving) That's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder,  as if to us) He prob'ly still has that gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...police cars approaching in BACKGROUND. PEARL hugs her  doll. JOHN is dazed. BEN stands, pistol in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you're bleeding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs JOHN'S shoulder and stoops as we TIGHTEN IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me son. You got to swear.  Swear means promise. First swear  you'll take care of little Pearl.  Guard her with your life, boy. Then  swear you won't never tell where  that money's hid. Not even your Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g. the TROOPERS get out of their cars and fan out  cautiously to surround BEN: guns in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got common sense. She ain't.  When you grow up that money'll be  yours. Now swear. "I will guard Pearl  with my life..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fumbling) I will guard Pearl with my life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."and I won't never tell about the  money."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I won't never tell about the  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Pearl. You swear too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggling) Who's them Blue Men yonder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under breath) Blue men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Harper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' now children. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN backs away from his CHILDREN, raising his hands, gun one hand. We PULL BACK a little, enlarging the GROUP SHOT and the role of the TROOPERS in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop that gun, Harper. We don't want  them kids hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO TROOPERS approach BEN from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just mind what you swore, son. Mind,  boy!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He runs forward and clasps his stomach, with his mouth op

dialogues.speaker: BEN AND TROOPERS
dialogues.text: One TROOPER smacks the back of BEN'S head with a pistol  barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting; a sickly  smile) Don't!

dialogues.speaker: BEN AND TROOPERS
dialogues.text: Another TROOPER, with a pistol barrel, knocks the pistol  from BEN'S lifted hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN sinks to his knees as both men, and two others from t front, close in on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes in the GROUP with his mouth open. o.s. we hear t slamming of car doors, and car starting away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: They drive away fast in road dust.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: Carrying a shopping bag, their mother, WILLA, runs up fro BACKGROUND between the CHILDREN, looking always to cars o

dialogues.speaker: WILLA
dialogues.text: She has a rich body.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PEARL comes to her and she picks up PEARL and the doll; J laden with his oath, walks quickly into the house. WILLA  does a bewildered take, then looks again towards the cars o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Harper, it is the sentence of  this Court that for the murder of Ed  Smiley and Corey South, you be hanged  by the neck until you are dead, and  may God have mercy on your soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies on his back, chuckling and murmuring indistinctly his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you all buffaloed! You ain't  never gonna git it outen me; not  none o' you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., very low) Where, Ben? Where? Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distinctly) And a little child shall lead them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN lies in profile. From the bunk above, the face of PRE stretches down into the SHOT, upside down, snake-like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Come on, boy: tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN wakes, sees PREACHER, and hits him so hard in the fac that he falls from bunk to floor. PREACHER collects himse into a squat, nursing his face. BEN sits up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with wholesome dignity) Ben, I'm a Man of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tryin' to make me talk about it in  my sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I say? (he grabs Preacher's  throat and shakes  him) What? What? What? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking) You was quotin' Scripture. You said --  you said, "And a little child shall  lead them."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies back, amused. PREACHER sits on the bedside; manne of a parson visiting the sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) You killed two men, Ben Harper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Preacher. I robbed  that bank because I got tired of  seein' children roamin' the woodlands  without food, children roamin' the  highways in this year of Depression;  children sleepin' in old abandoned  car bodies on junk-heaps; and I  promised myself I'd never see the  day when my youngins'd want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that ten thousand dollars I  could build a Tabernacle that'd make  the Wheeling Island Tabernacle look  like a chicken-house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have free candy for the  kids, Preacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up and wads a sock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it, Ben! With that cursed,  bloodied gold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you got that stickknife hid  in your bed-blankets, Preacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come not with Peace but with a  Sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Preacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREACHER gets and pockets the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Sword has served me through  many an evil time, Ben Harper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What religion do you profess,  Preacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The religion the Almighty and me  worked out betwixt us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salvation is a last-minute business,  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sock near mouth) Keep talkin', Preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you was to let that money serve  the Lord's purposes, He might feel  kindly turned towards you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talkin', Preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wads the sock into his mouth and lies back, sardonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice fading  into Dissolve) You reckon the Lord wouldn't change  his mind about you if...

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER'S HANDS
dialogues.text: They rest on sill of cell window, the lettered fingers  legible. The right hand is lettered L-O-V-E. The hands op disclosing his open knife. They close over it.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, AT CELL WINDOW
dialogues.text: His eyes lift from his hands, heavenward. Moonlight on hi face. He prays, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord You sure knowed what You was  doin' when You brung me to this very  cell at this very time. A man with  ten thousand dollars hid somewheres,  and a widder in the makin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same SHOT as before, but now, prison lights are on; and a man, a prison GUARD, waits close inside door. BART the HA joins him with a silent salute. BART wears a hard derby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence into MEDIUM, MOVING SHOT, the GUARD  talkative, BART reluctant to talk. The Penitentiary recedes in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a cool one, that Harper. Never  broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carried on some; kicked.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND GUARD
dialogues.text: On porch, by door, is a doll's perambulator. BART and GUA walk into the SHOT. GUARD stops, BART starts up his front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never told about the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking up steps) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you figure he done with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning, at door) He took the secret with him when I  dropped him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUARD leaves the SHOT; BART goes in.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He hangs up his coat and hat. Across this his wife speaks o.s.; a lighted door is ajar at rear of hall. A clatter o dishes and pans o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That you, Bart? Supper's waitin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART just nods, and, tiptoeing, walks into a door next th kitchen and snaps on a light and turns on water o.s. His  wife comes out of the kitchen and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is washing his hands in thick lather. Passing, she pec his cheek and, as we PAN, looks into the next room. He lo past her, and we see two small CHILDREN asleep in a big b bed. BART registers, turns again to the basin, and we PAN them back into the original TWO-SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Mother: sometimes I think it might  be better if I was to quit my job as  guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His WIFE'S eyes go sharp and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) You're always this way when there's  a hangin'. You never have to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BART rinses his hands. A sigh; he takes up the towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I was back at the  mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And leave me a widow after another  blast like the one in '24? Not on  your life, old mister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her a moment. She goes out. He looks o.s. tow his CHILDREN. He goes into their room on tiptoe.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He approaches his children, across whose bed WE SHOOT wit yet seeing them. He comes into MEDIUM CLOSE-UP. As he lea and we TILT DOWN, he extends his large hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two rose-and-gold little GIRLS lie in sleep; BART'S hands enter the SHOT and gently rearrange the covers so that th mouths and throats are free. We watch, for a moment more, the two sleeping faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. chanting) Hing, hang, hung. See what the Hangman  done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in Peacock Alley. The tree-shaded dirt street of a small, one-street river town; a picturesque, mid-19th-cen remnant of the old river civilization, which general prog has left behind. Chiefly we see, in this order: A schoolh (on far side of street); Miz Cunningham's second-hand sho a Grange House sporting a poster for a Western movie; Spo Ice Cream Parlor. At the end of this street, down the riv bank, is a brick wharf and UNCLE BIRDIE'S wharf-boat. In  b.g. and in passing, suggestions of sleepy small-town lif From the HEAD CLOSE-UP of BART the Hangman o.s. chanting,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chanting VOICES o.s. complete "see what the Hangman done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stroll barefoot down the empty dirt sidewalk. They l towards the voices, PEARL friendly, JOHN hostile.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, OVER JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: Several, within the door of the Schoolhouse, stick their  heads around the edge. They chant at the HARPER CHILDREN. Another, next the door, is drawing something on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Hung, hang, hing! See the Robber  swing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER these lines we CUT briefly to --

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: ...chanting, drawing. The ARTIST completes in chalk, a la simple sketch of a man hanging from gallows. As the verse ends we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, OVER JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: They look towards OUR CHILDREN; JOHN pays them no attenti The drawing is revealed. JOHN takes PEARL'S hand. The oth CHILDREN giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Hing, hang, hung! Now my song is  done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between lines one and two JOHN turns away from them into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SHOOT them through the window of MIZ CUNNINGHAM'S seco hand store. The back of a watch is silhouetted large in  FOREGROUND; JOHN'S eyes instantly fix on it; in b.g. the  SCHOOL-CHILDREN finish their song and vanish, giggling, i the schoolhouse. We hear the ticking of the watch.

dialogues.speaker: THE WATCH
dialogues.text: A watch with a moving sweep-hand, ticking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you goin' to buy it, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. JOHN'S eyes are fixed on the watch. OVER a sho doorbell we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Uh-Hawwww! (They glance toward  her.)

dialogues.speaker: MIZ CUNNINGHAM
dialogues.text: Fantastically dirty and fantastically dressed, she hustle to them and we PAN her into a THREE-SHOT. She talks like Tidewater Cockatoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) So your Mommy's keepin' you out of  school! Poor little lambs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL watches her; JOHN, the watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is your poor, poor mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at Spoon's Ice Cream Parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she snuffles) The Lord tends you both these days!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN doesn't take his eyes off the watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: His eyes are fixed on the watch o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Didn't they never find out what your  father done with all that money he  stole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes as before till "money," then he looks up towards her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they caught him, there wasn't  so much as a penny of it to be seen!  Now what do you make of that! Eh,  boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grins horribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl and me, we have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off fast as we DOLLY BEHIND THEM; he leads PEARL who hugs her doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Hing, hang, hung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not sing that song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you're too little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few paces in silence; now they come to the big window o Spoon's Ice Cream Parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get some candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA'S face is seen within; serving a customer, she sees them and waves them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps her strolling. WALT SPOON, comes out, proffering two lollypops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy, youngins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL drags at JOHN'S hand but JOHN, pretending not to se or hear, drags her out of the SHOT, shaking his head. We  DOLLY IN on WALT, who looks after them, surprised and tou then goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, WILLA, ICEY SP
dialogues.text: We PAN WALT across a little of his Parlor; he plants the  lollypops back in a jar on the counter and leaves the SHO as we TIGHTEN IN on WILLA and ICEY. WILLA slides used dis into wash-water; ICEY jaws down her back, from first mome of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willa Harper there is certain plain  facts of life that adds up just like  two plus two makes four and one of  them is this: No woman is good enough  to raise growin' youngsters alone!  The Lord meant that job for two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Icey, I don't want a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Fiddlesticks!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET
dialogues.text: The weekly movie audience is letting out, next door to  SPOON'S. Some start cars or wagons, others stroll to SPOO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start with a CLOSE SHOT as ICEY'S hands slap together gooey banana split; TILT UP to TWO-SHOT, favoring ICEY; f on WILLA, on "it's a man you need," etc. Murmur of CUSTOMERS o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling o.s.) One solid brown sody, one Lovers'  Delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tain't a matter of wantin' or not  wantin'! You're no spring chicken,  you're a grown woman with two little  youngins; it's a man you need in the  house, Willa Harper!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A short, lighted, toy-like train departs the town along t river-bank, whistling. The whistle TIES OVER the previous DISSOLVE. STARLIT SKY.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HARPER HOUSE
dialogues.text: A square, HEAD-ON SHOT, river water below and vibrant  starlight above; featuring a gas-lamp by the road; a tree and pretty tree-shadows which work across a window.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL, SHADOWS
dialogues.text: PEARL lies in their bed, her doll snug on her shoulder. J sits on the edge of the bed, in his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me a story, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once upon a time there was a rich  king... (he sees the shadows  on the wall and gets  up and looks at them) ...and he had him a son and a daughter  and they all lived in a castle over  in Africa. Well, one day this King  got taken away by bad men and before  he got took off he told his son to  kill anyone that tried to steal their  gold, and before long these bad men  come back and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blue Men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves, and as his shadow moves away we see the shadow PREACHER, motionless. PEARL sits up and points at it. JOH notices her and sees it. We PAN JOHN to the window. He lo out.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He stands motionless.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AT WINDOW
dialogues.text: He turns and we PAN him to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) Just a man. (he climbs into bed  and pulls up the  covers) Goodnight Pearl, sleep tight; and  don't let the bedbugs bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to doll) 'Night Miss Jenny; don't let the  bedbugs bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they settle down we hear PREACHER'S singing, sweet and quiet o.s.: "Leaning on the Everlasting Arms."

dialogues.speaker: SIDE-WHEELER
dialogues.text: She steams around a bend towards a toy-like small town.  PREACHER'S song, o.s., ties over. People are waving from  shore and boat.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT, FROM SHORE
dialogues.text: We PAN her into frame UNCLE BIRDIE STEPTOE'S toy-like lit wharf-boat. As she passes broadside we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE, THEN JOHN
dialogues.text: ...as boat passes. BIRDIE'S head sticks through a porthol He is a wiry old river character. The boat whistles. As B speaks we PAN JOHN, and foundered skiff, into TWO-SHOT wi BIRDIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't put in at Cresap's Landing  no more, but she still blows as she  passes. Come on in and have a cup of  coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting towards him) Ain't nobody stole Dad's skiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nobody goin' to neither, long  as Uncle Birdie's around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He vanishes from the porthole. We PAN JOHN from skiff to  wharf and Birdie's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling o.s.) First day my jints is limber enough  I'll haul her up and give her a good  caulkin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN enters and sits on a box. BIRDIE, in a ramshackle ro chair, pours coffee. BESS'S photograph on chest near BIRD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't seen you in a coon's age,  Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been mindin' Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pshaw now! Ain't it a caution what  women'll load onto a feller's back  when he ain't lookin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives JOHN a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, Cap, while I sweeten up  my coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fetches a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair about to pour he does a take at BESS'S PHOTOGRAPH.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: It stands in a cabinet frame: A fine-looking young woman archaic dress, with sharp, accusing black eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Dead and gone these twenty-five years  and never takes her eyes off me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT OVER his line to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the picture away and splashes liquor into his co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring) Man o' my years needs a little snort  to get his boiler heated of a morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drink. BIRDIE, satisfied, sighs and rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This mornin' I was talkin' to this  stranger up at the boarding-house.  He knowed your Dad!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: JOHN looks cautious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did he know Dad?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE
dialogues.text: BIRDIE'S face falls; he takes another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, boy, I'll not hide the truth;  it was up at Moundsville Penitentiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN puts his cup down and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to go now, Uncle Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shucks boy, you just got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows JOHN to the door. JOHN runs up the bank, not  looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running) I told Mom I'd be back to Spoon's  for Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He runs up the street close to Spoon's and stops dead.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He is horrified by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUP SHOT through door-glass, from JOHN'S VIEW POINT  PREACHER, WILLA and PEARL surround a little table. WALT s by, puffing his pipe. ICEY in BACKGROUND, stirs fudge at little soda-fountain stove. WILLA looks both moved and  pleased. PEARL, shyly flirting with PREACHER, all but hid in WILLA'S skirts. PREACHER dandles PEARL'S doll on his k as he talks. All the grownups are avid for his words, whi we don't hear through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We SHOOT THROUGH the DOOR; he quietly enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look casually to JOHN, and continue talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stirring; with a  meaningful glance at  Willa) God works in a mysterious way, His  wonders to perform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER this JOHN ENTERS the SHOT and stands at the fringe o the GROUP, staring at PREACHER'S hands and at the doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was with Brother Harper almost to  the end;...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...and now that I'm no longer employed  by the Penitentiary it is my joy to  bring this small comfort to his loved  ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On "Penitentiary" he glances quickly at PREACHER'S face;  then back to his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffing) It's a mighty good man would come  out of his way to bring a word of  cheer to a grieving widow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you ain't with the State no more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Brother; I resigned only  yesterday. The heart-renderin'  spectacle of them poor men was too  much for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He becomes aware of JOHN'S staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, little lad, you're staring at my  fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the doll to PEARL. JOHN'S eyes follow the doll.  PREACHER holds up both hands to JOHN. JOHN looks back at hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I tell you the little story of  Right-Hand-Left-Hand -- the tale of  Good and Evil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN stands still. PEARL, with her doll, crosses to PREAC and twines about his knee.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He looks on, in dumb alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H-A-T-E! (he thrusts up his  left hand) It was with this left hand that old  brother Cain struck the blow that  laid his brother low! L-O-V-E! (he thrusts up his  right hand) See these here fingers, dear friends!  These fingers has veins that lead  straight to the soul of man! The  right hand, friends! The hand of  Love!

dialogues.speaker: ICEY, WALT, WILLA
dialogues.text: They are impressed in their different ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Now watch and I'll show you the Story  of Life. The fingers of these hands,  dear hearts! -- They're always a- tuggin' and a-warrin' one hand agin'  t'other. (he locks his fingers  and writhes them,  crackling the joints) Look at 'em, dear hearts!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He looks on with unseeing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Old Left Hand Hate's a-fightin' and  it looks like Old Right Hand Love's  a goner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) But wait now! Hot dog! Love's a- winnin! Yessirree!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Love that won! Old Left Hand  Hate's gone down for the count! (he crashes both hands  onto the table)

dialogues.speaker: THE WHOLE GROUP
dialogues.text: Slight applause from the ADULTS. PREACHER takes PEARL, wi her doll, onto his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard it better told. I wish  every soul in this community could  git the benefit. You jest got to  stay for our church pick-nick Sunday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL offers PREACHER the DOLL to kiss. PREACHER complies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finessing it) I must wend my way down River on the  Lord's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't leavin' in no hurry if we  can help it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John: take that look offen your face  and act nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't mean no impudence; do you,  boy? (no answer) Do you, boy? Ah, many's the time  poor Brother Ben told me about these  youngins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he tell you?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He does a little take. His eyes twinkle palely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, he told me what fine little  lambs you and your sister both was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Something new enters his eyes; a game has begun between t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, no, boy; he told me lots and  lots of things. Nice things, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tight silence. ICEY pours fudge into a buttered pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, that fudge smells yummy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with horrid archness) It's for the pick-nick. And you won't  get a smidgen of my fudge unless you  stay for the pick-nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over her line, o.s., hymn-singing begins and now, OVER he "the case rests" smile we bring up the singing and

dialogues.speaker: THE SINGING PICKNICKERS
dialogues.text: A pleasant, grassy river-bank. Few men in proportion to w and children. We CENTER PREACHER. They are singing "Brigh the Corner;" PREACHER sings conspicuously well. The women watch him and admire him. He gives WILLA the eye as we PA to CENTER WILLA, who looks wooed and self-conscious. ICEY enters the SHOT and whispers and beckons WILLA and, as th singing continues, they leave the group and start towards shade tree in MEDIUM GROUND, which we PAN TO CENTER.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA AND ICEY
dialogues.text: They walk; singers in BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't he have the grandest singin'  voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA nods. ICEY, looking ahead, is displeased.

dialogues.speaker: THE TREE, JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: They sit on the bench, their backs to us, partly conceale by the tree trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) John! Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around. ICEY and WILLA enter the SHOT, their ba to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run along and play, you two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down by the river. My goodness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Docile, they leave the shot as WILLA and ICEY approach th bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on the bench, their back to us. The CHILDREN rec towards the river in BACKGROUND. WILLA meekly keeps her h down. Singing continues o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That feller's just achin' to settle  down with some nice woman and make a  home for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awful soon after Ben's passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ever I saw a Sign from Heaven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John don't like him much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl dotes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy worries me. It's silly, but  it's like there was something still  between him and his Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he needs is a dose o' salts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money, Icey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I declare, you'll let that money  haunt you to your grave, Willa Harper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would love to be satisfied Harry  Powell don't think I've got that  money somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll come right out and ask that  Man of God! (turning and yelling) Mr. Paow-well! (to Willa) Clear that evil mud out of your soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREACHER starts towards her. ICEY pivots and we PAN OVER to CHILDREN by river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) John! Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: PEARL AND JOHN
dialogues.text: JOHN looks up from pebble-skimming and loosens his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling o.s.) Come along hee-ere and get some fuu- udge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) I don't want no fudge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His brow is furrowed. He skims another pebble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting o.s.) You'll do what you're told!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They unwillingly get moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go set down by the River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Oh, Icey, I'm a sight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get along with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both women set off, WILLA to River, ICEY towards GROUP. W TRACK after ICEY. PREACHER approaches. ICEY, crossing him gives him a little shove towards WILLA and a coy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW her to the women who are busying themselves wit the fudge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a few men in BACKGROUND, and, beyond them, PREACHER si down by WILLA at water's edge. JOHN and PEARL approach. A ICEY starts yammering the men, WALT among them, shyly  withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That young lady'd better look sharp  or some smart sister between here  and Captina's a-gonna snap him up  right from under her nose! (they nod and agree,  ad lib) She's not the only fish in the river! (more agreement. John  and Pearl join Icey.  Icey speaks to John) Now you two stay put!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He looks hard towards WILLA and PREACHER o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., to women) Shilly-shallying around...

dialogues.speaker: WILLA AND PREACHER
dialogues.text: ...from JOHN'S VIEWPOINT in tableau of decorous courtship framed by heavy domestic bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) A husband's one piece of store goods  ye never know till you get it home  and take the paper off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit by the water; drooling willows; almost in traves of a romantic scene. WILLA dabbles one hand in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very shy) Did Ben Harper ever tell you what he  done with that money he stole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His head goes slantwise and he smiles oddly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear child, don't you know?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He watches intently towards his mother; PEARL holds his h ICEY'S voice o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's moonin' about Ben Harper. That  wasn't love, it was just flapdoodle. (agreeing nods and  murmurs) Have some fudge, lambs. (she hands some down  to John and Pearl.  Pearl smears her  mouth with it; John,  watching always  towards his mother,  takes one nibble and  throws the rest away) When you're married forty years, you  know all that don't amount to a hill  o'beans! I been married to my Walt  that long, and I'll swear in all  that time I'd just lie there thinking  about my canning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In BACKGROUND WALT looks sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling o.s.) John! John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All look towards her.

dialogues.speaker: OVER GROUP
dialogues.text: WILLA is standing, beckoning JOHN

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: They start towards their mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman's a fool to marry for that.  It's something for a man. The good  Lord never meant for a decent woman  to want that -- not really want it!  It's all just a fake and a pipe-dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others agree with her. She puts a piece of fudge in h mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as JOHN and PEARL (with DOLL) come shyly up. WILLA is  seated again. She is radiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, Mr. Powell has got something  to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, John, the night before your  father died, he told me what he did  with that money.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He desperately conceals his reaction; he thinks BEN has  betrayed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That money's at the bottom of the  river wrapped around a 12-pound  cobblestone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: He now conceals his new reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA touches PREACHER'S hand, warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks all around her, glowing, and stands up, hands t hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sshhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel clean now! My whole body's  just a quiverin' with cleanness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away towards ICEY and the WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John: here.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: JOHN moves to stand in front of him; PEARL, to stand besi PREACHER, with the DOLL.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: From JOHN'S eye-level; as JOHN steps in front of him and  PEARL beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tie's crooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand named LOVE and the hand named HATE come in to  straighten the necktie. JOHN looks down. He looks up and  sees:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: PREACHER, in close-up, hands busy o.s.; PEARL, with doll; and between them, in BACKGROUND, WILLA. She is now runnin fast towards ICEY, who walks towards her with arms  outstretched. Behind them, the group of WOMEN. BIRDIE'S g music begins o.s.

dialogues.speaker: AND SKIFF
dialogues.text: Birdie sits beside his open door, strumming a guitar and  singing. The scene is lamplighted from within. Ben's skif is inverted on trestles in FOREGROUND. At start of scene see only JOHN's feet; he's under the skiff, examining it. After three lines of song he comes out from under, and lo against the skiff, tracing a tarry seam with his forefing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) 'Twas down at Cresap's Landing, Along  the River Shore, Birdie Steptoe was  a Pilot in the good old days of yore.  Now he sets in his old wharf-boat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across him) When'll Dad's skiff be ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't hear ye, boy. (singing) ...So the big boats heave a sigh,  They blow for Uncle Birdie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across him) When'll the skiff be ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) And the times that are gone by. I'll  have her ready inside of a week; and  then we'll go fishin'. How's your  Maw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through rest of scene, Birdie picks lazily at his guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O, she's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your sister Pearl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leavin', boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep; gotta watch out for Pearl, Uncle  Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well goodnight, boy. Come again --  any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN leaves the SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And mind now -- I'll have your Paw's  skiff in ship-shape, 'side of a week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: As he runs past SPOON'S, looking in, he is curious.

dialogues.speaker: SPOON'S, HIS VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: ICEY embraces WILLA or waltzes her around; WALT looks on, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He hurries away from us towards home.

dialogues.speaker: THE HARPER HOUSE
dialogues.text: In the otherwise dark house, one window is lighted. JOHN  enters the SHOT, his back to us. Seeing the lighted windo he hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Is somebody there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent pause, listening; then he walks cautiously towards us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: A tall, narrow shooting-frame; right and left thirds of s are black. We SHOOT from inside the screen door. JOHN crosses the po and softly opens the door and enters on tiptoe and pauses close to us, in the dark hallway, listening sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Is anybody here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Relieved, but puzzled, he tiptoes along towards rear of the hallway in CLOSE-UP as we PULL AWAY. We bring the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Good evening, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN gasps, peering, and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND PREACHER
dialogues.text: PREACHER looks at JOHN; JOHN sinks onto the edge of a cha PREACHER sits opposite. A bar of light from door falls ac PREACHER'S face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a little talk with your mother  tonight, John; and your mother decided  it might be best for me to -- let  you know the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From JOHN, just a questioning helpless reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother told me tonight she wanted  me to be a daddy to you and your  sister. We're going to get married,  son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN is still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married! We have decided to go to  Sistersville tomorrow, and when we  come back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just breathing it) You ain't my Dad! You won't never be  my Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obsessed, disregarding  him) -- and when we come back, we'll all  be friends -- and share our fortunes  together, John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) You think you can make me tell! But  I won't! I won't! I won't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gawks at his own folly, covers his mouth with his hand and looks up at PREACHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Tell me what, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we keeping secrets from each  other, little lad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: stiffens, relaxes, and chuckles softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter, boy, we've got a long  time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN starts for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stands vibrating, then moves out of shot with receding engine sound o.s., disclosing:

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: ICEY'S skirts in BACKGROUND. They are awfully spic-and-sp they even wear shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Wave yer hands! Great sakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wave after the car, bewilderedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) You wait here while I get your night- things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hustles out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now can I tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Mr. Powell's our Daddy then I  can tell him about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand clamps over her mouth. She struggles and whimper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You swore, Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across him) John! Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised Dad you wouldn't never  tell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his hand away but holds it ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Mr. Powell lots and lots,  John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN grabs her by the shoulders and glares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you tell! Don't you NEVER DARE  tell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over them we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is caressing her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA
dialogues.text: Her back is to us. She is in a pathetic night dress; she  stands before a mirror in a hotel bedroom in Sistersville She walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hesitates on the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA
dialogues.text: Shooting OVER her as she opens the door, we see PREACHER bed, his back to us. Beyond him, a window. The drawn shad rustles quietly.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: ...from within the room. WILLA closes the door, on which  PREACHER'S coat hangs. The closing brings a knocking soun WILLA feels the outside of the coat; feels something hard takes out the knife and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: THE KNIFE IN HER HAND
dialogues.text: A moment of perplexity; then a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Oh! It's... uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts it back in the pocket and gives the pocket a pat She starts towards the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: We SHOOT OVER PREACHER as she approaches modestly and sta by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Harry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand comes up; she puts out her own, expecting a lovi hand-clasp; but PREACHER points to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fix that window shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, then again tender, she moves to:

dialogues.speaker: WILLA AT WINDOW
dialogues.text: She adjusts the shade, looking always towards the bed. Sh smiles maternally. As we PULL BACK and PAN into FULL SHOT BED she comes to the bed and sits on the edge and slips o her mules. PREACHER'S back is to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Harry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool and clear) I was praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Harry! I didn't know!  I thought maybe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sounding of bedsprings PREACHER turns. His voice i quiet and cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought, Willa, that the moment  you walked in that door I'd start in  to pawing you in the abominable way  men are supposed to do on their  wedding night. Ain't that right,  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Harry! I thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time we got one thing  perfectly clear, Willa. Marriage to  me represents a blending of two  spirits in the sight of Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out of bed. WILLA puts her face down to the pillo and moans. PREACHER snaps on a harsh bare bulb at center of room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Get up, Willa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go and look at yourself yonder  in that mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA walks to meet her image in the mirror; her eyes on  PREACHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOOK at yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her head drops, facing the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA, PREACHER, BULB
dialogues.text: WILLA is in HEAD CLOSE-UP; bulb hangs at center; PREACHER in his nightshirt, is beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see, girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mouth trembles; she can't talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the body of a woman! The  temple of creation and motherhood.  You see the flesh of Eve that Man  since Adam has profaned. That body  was meant for begetting children. It  was not meant for the lust of men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA just opens her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want more children, Willa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- no, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the business of our marriage to  mind those two you have now -- not  to beget more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands watching her for a moment; then he snaps off th light and gets into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can get back into bed now and  stop shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA, in the darkness, does not move. She folds her hand in prayer and lifts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Help me to get clean so I can be  what Harry wants me to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) AAA-MEN!

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: A dozen country men and women in religious ecstasy. (NOTE: No set necessary for this scene. Flare, or flares, every SHOT. Faces lighted by flares.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AAA-MENN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., very loud) You have all sinned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But which one of you can say as I  can say: I drove a good man to murder  because I kept a-houndin' him for  clothes and per-fumes and face paint!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) And he slew two human beings and he  come to me and he said: Take this  money and buy your per-fumes and  paint!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Brethren, that's where the Lord  stepped in! That's where the LORD  stepped in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o. s.) Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. screaming) And the Lord told that man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord said, Take that money and  throw it in the River!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yes! Yes! Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw that money in the River! In  THE RIVER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) IN THE RIIV-ER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It lies face down on arbor bricks, its back wide open; mo spilling out. A little breeze toys with the money. HOLD, moment, in silence. Then we hear a snipping sound o.s. TI UPWARD into --

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: She sits at the end of the grape-arbor. She finishes cutt a skirted paperdoll out of a hundred dollar bill and lays down beside a male hundred-dollar paper-doll. She pats th dolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! You're John -- and you're Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. calling) Pearl?... Pearl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL starts guiltily and looks towards him, scrambling m together. JOHN'S footsteps o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get awful mad, John. I done a  Sin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears the frantic rustling of paper --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) Pearl! You ain't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, don't be mad! Don't be mad! I  was just playing with it! I didn't  tell no one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as he stoops toward her, dumb with horror.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: She continues to gather the money together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) It's all here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl! Oh, Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's stuffing bills back into the torn doll. They slide  through her fingers. He helps.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER'S FOOT
dialogues.text: ...as he plants it, with sound, in damp grass.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: JOHN freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- yes?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He stands at far end of arbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting Pearl to bed. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's taking you so long about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) It -- she --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that you're playing with,  boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl's junk. Mom gets mad when she  plays out here and don't clean up  afterward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, children!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: PREACHER'S watch-chain gleams. The shot SLOWLY CLOSES DOW on it and becomes still. We see the paper-dolls blow past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, up to bed with the both of you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: JOHN starts to laugh uncontrollably. We PAN them past  PREACHER'S stomach into FULL SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, John. Run along, Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL goes, JOHN comes towards PREACHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother says you tattled on me,  boy. She says you told her that I  asked you where that money was hid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't very nice of you, John.  Have a heart, boy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: His helpless reaction. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run along to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JOHN turns away we

dialogues.speaker: WILLA IN PROFILE
dialogues.text: ...and PULL AWAY showing JOHN as he turns to her. (PEARL' head is turned away; she's asleep.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you impudent to Mr. Powell,  John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I didn't mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you impudent about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me about the money again,  Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always make up that lie, John!  There is no money, John. Can't you  get that through your head?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND BIRDIE
dialogues.text: They look down into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanest, orneriest, sneakinest critter  in the whole river, boy! A gar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit up into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your can o' hooks, Uncle  Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There hain't nary hook in the land  smart enough to hook Mister Gar.  What a feller needs is mother-wit --  and a horse-hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over this, he pulls horse-hair out of his hatband. He set to work rigging his noose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't he bust it, Uncle Birdie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot, a horse-hair'll hold a lumpin'  whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts over his line. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind me cussin', boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you why I ask -- your step-pa  being' a Preacher an' all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN's lips go like string. BIRDIE sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never was much of a one for preachers  myself. I dunno what's wrong up at  your place, but just remember one  thing, Cap -- if ever you need help  you just holler out and come a- runnin'. Old Uncle Birdie's your  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A powerful strike. BIRDIE lands the gar. The air is full sparkling water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There! You slimy, snag-toothed, egg- suckin', bait-stealin' so-and-so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He beats the fish with the heel of an old shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beating) Mind what I told you. If ever you  get in a crack, I just come a-runnin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there is no sound of thumping or beating.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Admiring BIRDIE, he squares his shoulders, full of confid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we eat him, Uncle Birdie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got an appetite for bones and  bitterness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this, he flings the dead gar in a wide arc out into th river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Smiling, quiet, awaiting an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: PEARL plays unconcernedly in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intimately) She thinks that money's in the river,  but you and me, we know better, don't  we, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The summer is young yet, little lad. (he turns away from  John) Pearl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hands to her; she comes to his lap, drop her doll at his feet. JOHN turns his back and looks out t window beside bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's a feller who likes to keep  secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knowed your Daddy. (PEARL frowns) And do you know what your Daddy said  to me? He said, "Tell my little girl  Pearl there's to be no secrets between  her and you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What secret shall I tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no secret. I'm five.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: A look of impotent hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, that's no secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggling) You're just foolin'! My name's Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tst-tst! Then I reckon I'll have to  try again! Where's the money hid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN throws the hairbrush, striking PREACHER's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming as he throws) You swore you wouldn't tell! (he beats the air  with his fists) You swore! You swore! You swore!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He is sure now PEARL knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed) You hit Daddy with the hairbrush!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) You see? We can't have anything to  do with John. (light off) You and me will go down to the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Jenny! Miz Jenny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets the doll. We PAN them through the door.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: Outside door as he closes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's just plumb bad through and  through --

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: As PREACHER's hand locks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at door) Yes, John's just plumb bad.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: We shoot over ICEY as WILLA opens the door to leave. WILL is in outdoor clothes and is not dressed for work in the  parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That boy's as stubborn and mulish as  a sheep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA's face shines like one possessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALT enters shot, his back to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As WILLA starts away we DOLLY THROUGH DOOR and PAN her to deserted street. There is a river mist.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: WALT is ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. calling) Plan on a longer visit next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) You don't hardly get settled till  you're frettin' to git home again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again WILLA pauses and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sweet radiance.  To Walt) I'm needed to keep peace and harmony  between them. (to Icey) It's my burden and I'm proud of it,  Icey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off into the mist.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: Distant muffled sound of river-boat whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) John's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA enters, her back to us; she stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yes; John's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me another secret about my Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA
dialogues.text: She smiles benignly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) O no! Your turn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the money hid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLA keeps smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the money hid? Tell me, you  little wretch, or I'll tear your arm  off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still smiling, shaking her head as in disbelief, WILLA ma for house as PEARL screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narrow screen, same set-up as in earlier corridor scene,  PREACHER and WILLA. Their eyes meet. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) I didn't expect you home so soon.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA
dialogues.text: She still smiles; her eyes turn to sound of PEARL's sobbi

dialogues.speaker: AS BEFORE
dialogues.text: PREACHER stands still; WILLA in BACKGROUND opens closet d where PEARL sobs.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: ...washing and drying glasses. ICEY is washing briskly, W is drying slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Icey, I'm worried about Willa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm figurin' how I can say it so's  you won't get mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what, Walt Spoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's somethin' wrong about it,  Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Mr. Powell. All of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mother, a body can't help their  feelin's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May the Lord have mercy on you, Walt  Spoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I only --

dialogues.speaker: BED
dialogues.text: WILLA lies in profile on the bed along the bottom of the  frame. A prim, old woman's nightdress makes her look like child. Her hands are clasped. PREACHER, fully dressed, stands at the window, which is i BACKGROUND towards foot of bed. His coat, hung over a cha is in silhouette. River mist outside window halated by  exterior gas-lamp. The window shade is up. She is mumblin in prayer. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his back still turned) Are you through praying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. WILLA is calm and immobile with the ecstasy of martyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were listening outside the parlor  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not in the river, is it Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben never told you he throwed it in  the river? Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREACHER hits her across the mouth. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues, unruffled) Then the children know where it is  hid? John knows? Is that it? (a pause) Then it's still here, somewhere  amongst us, tainting us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you must have known it all along,  Harry.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, LISTENING
dialogues.text: After a moment, the river boat whistle blows, nearer. HOL CLOSE-UP a moment after whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that ain't why you married me,  Harry. I know that much. It couldn't  be that because the Lord just wouldn't  let it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made you marry me so's you could  show me the Way and the Life and the  Salvation of my soul! Ain't that so,  Harry?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He has heard the VOICE and starts to move out of CLOSE SH

dialogues.speaker: RESUME TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: He has moved over to the coat on back of chair.

dialogues.speaker: COAT
dialogues.text: His hand goes into the pocket and brings the knife out. ( is the same coat, and pocket, as in the wedding-night sce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you might say it was the money  that brung us together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls down the blind. He moves toward the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of it don't matter, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT -- PREACHER's HAND AND KNIFE It clicks open.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: As he raises his arm to strike:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless us all!

dialogues.speaker: WALL
dialogues.text: They are shaped as in earlier scene, but altered by mist. Set-up as in earlier scene. Over them we hear the whinny- catch and the failure of the Ford being cranked; once; th again: the JOHN's shadow moves on the wall and on a third cranking which engages the engine, we PAN TO WINDOW, shoo over JOHN, who peers out, into blind mist. The gears of t car shift; the car moves away, unseen; its sounds diminis slowly, and die. A moment of silence; then JOHN turns and PAN him to the bed. He gets in beside PEARL, who is aslee and, as we TIGHTEN IN CLOSE, puts his hand across the fac of the doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ominous expression. She looks sharp to WALT, beckoning secretly; through rear screen door of kitchen, onto porch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud whisper) Walt! Come quick!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: He is scrubbing out an ice cream container on the back po He looks up and moves towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (natural voice) What's wrong, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper) Sshhh! He's in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALT ENTERS SHOT with pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper) Mr. Powell! (Walt looks enquiry) Willa has run away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be switched!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the kitchen. We hear muffled sounds of sobbing o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just went?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took out some time durin' the  night, -- in that old Model-T --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALT clucks his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he hit pretty bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All to pieces!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALT moves towards kitchen cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a little peach brandy --  maybe a sip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man of the Cloth?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: He pours, snaps it down; weak-defiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt Spoon, that's for sickness in  the house!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: He looks towards o.s. sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought if you went and talked to  him -- another man --

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He sits at a table, his back towards us, mumbling over hi Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Powell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly loud) A strange woman is a narrow pit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a reverent whisper) Amen! Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lieth in wait as for a prey. And  increaseth the transgressors among  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his Bible and turns to them with weepy eyes and brave little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, dear friends! Whatever would  I do without you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wailing) Mister Powell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anythin' -- anythin'...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my shame -- my crown of thorns.  And I must wear it bravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could have possessed that girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Satan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALT sits across from PREACHER. ICEY is at PREACHER's elb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you have no inkling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes; from the first night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turned me out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pleasure) Nnnoooo!!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Filling his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you figure to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do? Why stay and take care of them  little kids. Maybe it was never meant  for a woman like Willa to taint their  young lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands clasped; with  approval) Mmmmm!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dabbing at moisture in the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's mighty brave of you, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon it's been ordained this  way, Brother Spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't -- didn't she leave no word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scrawl. On a piece of notepaper on  the bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICEY smiles sideways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I burned it. (Preacher holds out  his hand, stares in  disgust, and wipes  his palm dramatically  on his coatsleeve) I tore it up and burned it -- it  stank so strong of hellfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pitcher has went to the well  once too often, my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll come draggin' her tail back  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll not be back. I reckon I'd be  safe in promisin' you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's just run off on a spree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's no harm in hopin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no sense in it, neither. I  figured somethin' like this was  brewin' when she went to bed last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all woman) How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tarried around the kitchen after  I'd gone up, and when I went  downstairs to see what was wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd found this fruit jar of  dandelion wine (Icey touches him) that the husband -- Harper -- had  hid somewheres in the cellar. (playing his ace) She was drinking.

dialogues.speaker: ICEY
dialogues.text: ICEY is happy to let her mouth fall open and let out a ga

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sniffling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to save her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you did, Reverend. Oh, I know  how you tried!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The devil wins sometimes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes upturned) Can't nobody say I didn't do my best  to save her!
