dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN, with slowly streaming weeds, and bring in WILLA i close profile; the current, coming from behind her, drift her long hair across her throat.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA AND CAR
dialogues.text: She is in profile as before --

dialogues.speaker: A BAITED HOOK
dialogues.text: It descends, and catches on the windshield, and the line  tautens; then tugs. We start to follow the line up.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE WATER
dialogues.text: We continue to follow the line up, and bring in, close, t stern of BEN HARPER's skiff.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE BIRDIE
dialogues.text: He sits back, tugging unconcernedly at the line. Then he  leans over to see what's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE
dialogues.text: ...as he peers over side.

dialogues.speaker: WILLA
dialogues.text: We hear PREACHER's voice o.s., singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Leaning! Leaning! Safe and secure  from all alarms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile we move vertically DOWNWARD TOWARDS HER FACE, s in death. We may or may not glimpse the gashed throat, th drifting hair.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE AND TREE
dialogues.text: PREACHER leans against the tree; he continues singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning! Leaning! Leaning on the  Everlasting Arms! (seductively) Children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start moving before he does. LOW CAMERA; full figure. TILT to frame him from the waist downward and follow clos behind him. As he leaves the tree and walks along the sid of the house; we TILT DOWNWARD and CLOSE IN, to follow on his feet; he steps past a tiny cellar window and we PAN a TIGHTEN IN CLOSE ON IT, into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their noses are flat against the glass; their cheeks touc their window isn't quite big enough to hold both their he It is on the ground; we don't see their chins. They look  towards the departed PREACHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Chill-dren?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL, who is on the side PREACHER has left by, turns her head towards JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are standing on a coal heap, faces at window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, why do we have to hide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN has taken charge. He speaks very quietly, but calmly and cheerfully, as to an invalid. He starts down the rust coal-heap, helping PEARL down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following dialogue as they climb down, making as litt noise as possible. We PULL slowly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone to Moundsville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I reckon that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have achieved the cellar floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more peremptorily  outside) Children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the following dialogue we hear, o.s., the opening a door, and PREACHER'S footsteps indoors as he crosses fl climbs stairs, and opens another door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is after us, Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go upstairs. It's cold and  spidery down here. I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen to me, Pearl. You and me  is runnin' off tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we stay here somethin' awful will  happen to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't Daddy Powell take care of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's just it. No.

dialogues.speaker: A ROOM UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: PREACHER looks under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we goin', John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewheres. I don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., PREACHER'S footsteps come down stairs; JOHN leads P carefully past a rake, a hoe, and a shelf-prop and they c down into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...beside an apple barrel. PREACHER'S footsteps cross kit o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll steal somethin' to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll spoil our supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Pearl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both look sharp towards cellar door o.s.

dialogues.speaker: THE CELLAR DOOR
dialogues.text: The door opens; PREACHER'S head, carrying a candle in hol a white-washed wall and stairs are lighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you whisperin', children, so  I know you're down there. I can feel  myself gettin' awful mad, children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) John...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN claps his hand over her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My patience has run out, children.  I'm comin' to find you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clop-clops nearly to the bottom of the stairs. ICEY'S  voice cuts cheerfully across his descent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling o.s.) Yoo-Hooooo! Mis-ter Paow-welll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes up the stairs and vanishes. Light on wall through open door to kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little hot supper I fixed for  you and the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you, bless you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're down there playin' games in  the cellar and they won't mind me  when I call 'em. I'm at my wit's  end, Miz Spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICEY clucks her tongue o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) John: Pearl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She appears at head of stairs. Her voice crackles with  authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John! Pearl! Shake a leg! (she claps her hands  sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I won't have you worryin' poor Mister  Powell another minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause; then the children, covered with coal-dust, emerge into the light and climb the stairs. JOHN'S head i hung in defeat. As they enter the kitchen we PULL BACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look at you! Dust and filth  from top to toe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to take 'em up and wash 'em  good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, no. Thank you, dear Icey.  I'll tend to them. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICEY pats JOHN'S head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too hard on 'em, Reverend.  Poor motherless children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks to PEARL and we PAN HER IN as PREACHER'S hand  named LOVE moves through her locks. We PAN with PREACHER ICEY as they move towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember now Mister Powell, don't be  afraid to call on us. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He watches ICEY leave, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Good night Miz Spoon, and thank you  again.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER AND ICEY
dialogues.text: ICEY goes away along path outside. PREACHER, his back to watches her a moment, then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't you afraid, my little lambs,  down there in all that dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wondering what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE, OVER BESS'S PICTURE
dialogues.text: We begin with HEAD CLOSE-UP of BIRDIE as he rocks, and PU BACK He is rocking; and drunk. A bottle stands beside the picture. He turns and speaks to the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll think it was me! They'll  think it was old Uncle Birdie!

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE
dialogues.text: His hands grip the edge of the chest on either side of th picture, which we now see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd o' seen it, Bess! I'm drunk  as a lord and I know it, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. continuing) Sweet Heaven, if you'd o' seen it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIRDIE picks up the bottle. His hand and the liquor tremb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Down there in the deep place... her  hair wavin' lazy and soft like meadow  grass under flood waters and that  slit in her throat just like she had  an extry mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) And there ain't mortal human I can  tell but you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...Bess, for if I go to the Law  they'll hang it on to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottle falls from his hand onto its side on the edge the chest.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE
dialogues.text: The reverse angle of the opening shot. BIRDIE rocks heavi liquor gurgles from bottle to floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Heaven save poor old Uncle  Birdie!

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER sits at head of table. JOHN stands to PREACHER'S right, around corner of table; he remains expressionless immobile, until he speaks. PEARL stands to JOHN'S right,  hugging the DOLL. The table is loaded with good food. PREACHER, well-fed and at leisure, dabs his mouth delicat with his napkin, folds it, puts it in a ring, and folds h hands. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at last) I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, sure. And there's fried chicken  and candied sweets and cornsticks  and apple cobbler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have my supper please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have milk too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But first of all we'll have a  little talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL frowns and puts her finger in her mouth; she rememb he twisted her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) About our secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, pray tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because John said I mustn't.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT REVERSE
dialogues.text: He slaps the table; his eyes crackle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEVER -- MIND -- WHAT -- JOHN --  SAID!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL starts to snivel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is a meddler. Stop sniveling.  Looky here a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brings out the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL shakes her head for no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to see something cute? Looky  now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches the spring; the blade flicks open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that! This is what I use  on meddlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays the open knife on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John might be a meddler.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PEARL thinks the knife is a toy and crosses behind JOHN t pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO -- no, my lamb. Don't touch it!  Now don't touch my knife! That makes  me mad. Very, very mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs the DOLL and he puts the hand named LOVE on her  curls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me now; where's the money  hid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectionately) But I swore. I promised John I  wouldn't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN -- DOESN'T -- MATTER! Can't I  get that through your head, you poor,  silly, disgusting little wretch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mouth quivers; a large tear brims in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There now! You made me lose my temper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry! I'm real sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL sniffles and wipes her eyes with her free fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a caressing tone) Now! Where's it hid, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly and lightly) I'll tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) I thought I told you to keep your  mouth shut --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (light and quick) NO, -- it ain't fair to make Pearl  tell when she swore she wouldn't.  I'll tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREACHER'S EYES CRINKLE and he turns to PEARL, smiling  brightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Well I declare! Sometimes I think  poor John will make it to heaven  yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes snap back to JOHN and his voice is like a whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right boy: where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cellar. Buried under a stone  in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: He closes and pockets the knife. His eyes never leave JOH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll go hard, boy, if I find you're  lyin'.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PEARL gapes up at JOHN as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't lyin'. Go look for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: ...as he gets up, cellar door in BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... (he turns towards the  door; then glances  around) Come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead of me -- the both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross him, towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE CELLAR STEPS
dialogues.text: The CHILDREN precede PREACHER, who carries a candle in ho PEARL is gaping at JOHN'S lie. JOHN is looking left and r casing the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You don't reckon I'd leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with forced lightness) Don't you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically) Why sure, boy, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they are at bottom of stairs. JOHN sees PEARL'S expre and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where, boy? Mind; no tricks. I  can't abide liars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezes PEARL'S hand harder, and points.

dialogues.speaker: NEW ANGLE
dialogues.text: JOHN points out a place beneath a shelf laden with Mason  jars; it is at the most distant part of the cellar from t stairs. PREACHER starts toward it, leaving them at foot of stairs then turns, catching JOHN'S ruse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic) O no you don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shepherds them ahead of him.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: They arrive beneath the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying magnificently,  meeting Preacher's  eyes) Under the stone in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREACHER sets the candle on a barrel near the shelf-prop sinks to his knees below shot as PEARL gapes at JOHN and  JOHN looks stony. She seems about to speak.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, FEATURING FLOOR
dialogues.text: His hands sweep dust and expose concrete. He straightens his knees and turns to the children in close BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as he turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment's silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John made a Sin. John told a lie.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER gets slowly to his feet and puts on his "listeni look. His sincerity is beyond doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord's a-talkin' to me now. He's  a-sayin', "a liar is an abomination  before mine eyes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his knife out, and springs it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak, boy: Where's it hid? (the knife pricks the  flesh under John's  ear) Speak; before I cut your throat and  leave you to drip like a hog hung up  in butcherin' time!

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: She starts to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl, shut up! Pearl, you swore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could save him, little bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Inside my doll! Inside my doll!

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER is astounded. His hands fall away from JOHN. He  leans back against the wall and talks through laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the doll! Why sure! Sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) The last place anyone would look!

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER makes a lunge across JOHN for the doll; JOHN duc under his arm, pulls PEARL forward with his left hand; he turns backwards and with his free hand, in one movement,  knocks over the candle and pulls out the support on the s

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Jars shower over him; one crowns him and breaks, shedding guck, which he wipes from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: They start up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He makes one step forward, steps on a rolling jar, and fa

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: They are near the top of the stairs. We hear PREACHER bel them. JOHN slips and they nearly fall backward. As JOHN  recovers, PREACHER enters the shot, his back to us. The  children get through the open door as PREACHER reaches to JOHN slams the door, catching PREACHER'S hand. PREACHER  screams. JOHN'S astonished eyes peer through the crack in the door; the door loosens; PREACHER yanks his hand loose and sucks it, groaning; the door slams to; the bolt is sh home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...over sound of slamming bolt. He snarls like the Big Ba Wolf. All the above happens at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL, dangling her doll, cries. JOHN panting, leans agai wall by door. JOHN is wondering what to do now. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., sweetly) Chilll-dren? (continuing) The only reason I wanted that money  is so's you could have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself; panting) The river. That's the only where!  Uncle Birdie Steptoe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cooing) Puhr-urrl? Want your Mommy back? (Pearl hugs her doll) Want me to get her right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush, Pearl. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fly out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing, as they  go) OPEN THAT DOOR, YOU SPAWN OF THE  DEVIL'S OWN STRUMPET!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARPER HOUSE
dialogues.text: A pretty, pastoral shot of the house in light mist, as th run across and leave the shot. Before they disappear, we  hear PREACHER'S fists hammering against the door. We stay the house at leisure; we hear him lunging, shoulder to do we begin to hear squeaking of hinges and splintering of w

dialogues.speaker: FRAMING BIRDIE'S WHARF-BOAT
dialogues.text: An ultra romantic image of shelter and peace. Frogs or ri noises o.s., then the rattle of running footsteps. The  children center, their backs to us, sprinting towards the boat. Light mist as in previous shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Uncle Birdie! Uncle Birdie!

dialogues.speaker: BIRDIE AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: We shoot over BESS'S turned photograph and over BIRDIE, c passed out in his rocker. The children run through open d in BACKGROUND and JOHN runs up to BIRDIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Birdie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing feebly) Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hide us Uncle Birdie! He's a-comin'  with his knife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs BIRDIE'S shoulder; BIRDIE half-rises, and falls  face down on floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me! John Harper and Pearl! You  said to come a-runnin' if we needed  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIRDIE rears on one elbow and looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in friendly  recognition) Johnny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He falls face down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN grabs BIRDIE by one ear, turning his face up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle -- Birdie! Oh -- please! Please  wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up earnestly at JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never done it, boy. Sweet Heaven I  never done such a terrible thing!  I'll swear on the Book to it, boy! I  never done it! I never!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He is lost; and he becomes a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Lord save poor old Uncle Birdie  Steptoe that never hurt a fly! (he snores, softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) There's still the river. -- The skiff  is down by the willows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He masterfully takes PEARL by the hand and leads her into the night.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: We shoot from the river. They struggle through the sumac pokeberry weeds at edge of river, towards skiff, whose pr tethered to willow, we see throughout this un-moving shot at our extreme right. When they come opposite skiff -- wh is a few yards out from shore --

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: PEARL, frankly bored, dangling her doll, is yawning. JOHN as he finishes undoing rope from a willow root, looks up around, checking on pursuit. His eyes fix.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER'S SHADOW
dialogues.text: On the bank above, it is huge in the mist. Same camera  position as foregoing; new angle.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: BACK view: skiff in BACKGROUND. Same camera position; new angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Please be quiet -- Oh please, Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (natural voice) John, where are we g --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush.

dialogues.speaker: SHADOW, THEN PREACHER
dialogues.text: Same position and angle as before. PREACHER'S own figure advances to supplant his shadow. He peers downward, his open knife catching the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (businesslike) Children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts slashing his way down through the brush-filth.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Same camera position as before. They are floundering thro mud, half-way to the skiff.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Same position and angle as in previous shot of him. He is half-way down the bank. With his knife, he hacks at an  entangling vine.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Position and angle as before. They reach the skiff. Hacki sounds o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the skiff, Pearl, goodness,  goodness, hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant) That's Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks her up and throws her into the skiff.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL AND DOLL
dialogues.text: ...as they land, sprawling, in bottom of skiff among fish heads and bait cans. JOHN gets in after them.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He tears free of brush to edge of river, knife glittering

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: With his oar, he tries to push the boat free of mud.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He wades towards them, knee-deep in mud.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He is shoving at the oar even more desperately.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S HANDS
dialogues.text: Straining.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He flounders deeper and more heavily through the mud; muc closer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He pushes the boat free of mud.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He hurries much closer through shallow water. Prow of boa in FOREGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, you little whelps! Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another step forward and he does a pratt-fall and makes a splash.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He is trying to feather the boat out to where the current will catch it. In panic and haste he is clumsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I do it when I know how to  do it!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: ...as he gets up, at edge of mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Wait! I'll slit your guts!

dialogues.speaker: FULL DOWN-SHOT
dialogues.text: The current catches it and spins it round like a leaf. JO efforts with the oars are useless. PREACHER enters, wadin fast. His hands are within an inch of reaching the helple skiff; capriciously the current takes it downstream.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: The skiff is taken steadily by the current. PEARL sits up doll in arms. JOHN is almost asleep with exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKIFF, OVER PREACHER
dialogues.text: It is well away from him and getting smaller. Waist-deep, wades a couple of steps after it, then just looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins a steady, rhythmical, animal scream of outrage loss.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: JOHN is asleep. PEARL sits sleepily whispering to her dol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once upon a time there was a pretty  fly, and he had a wife, this pretty  fly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) ...and one day she flew away, and  then one night his two pretty fly  children...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., continuing) ...flew away too, into the sky, into  the moon...

dialogues.speaker: A FROG, AND SKIFF
dialogues.text: A big frog is profiled; the skiff drifts by in distance; frog twangs out a bass-note.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE POSTCARD
dialogues.text: As the card is turned to the handwritten side we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) Dear Walt and Icey: I bet you been  worried and gave us up for lost.  Took the kids down here with me for  a visit to my sister Elsie's farm.  Thot a little change of scenery would  do us all a world of good after so  much trubble and heartache. At least  the kids will git a plenty of good  home cooking. Your devoted Harry  Powell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now ain't you relieved, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but you was worried too, Mother;  takin' off with never a word of  goodbye. I even got to figurin' them  gypsies busted in and done off with  all three of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your gypsies! They been gone  a week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not before one of 'em knifed a farmer  and stole his horse. Never caught  the gypsies nor the horse.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIVER
dialogues.text: A man is going along a river lane on horseback. It is PREACHER; he walks the horse away from us.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER BEND OF THE RIVER
dialogues.text: We descend to a poor riverside farmhouse; JOHN and PEARL  tether a boat in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: AND PEARL
dialogues.text: They are eating hot boiled potatoes. A glance at JOHN and PEARL, and they turn away towards lane in BACKGROUND. JOH and PEARL proceed towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, PEARL, WOMAN, THROUGH DOOR
dialogues.text: We shoot from within open door of kitchen. JOHN and PEARL advance to edge of porch. A TIRED FARM WOMAN stands by do within. We shoot OVER her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry, I s'pose. Well, I'll see if  there's any more potatoes to spare.  Where's your folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't got none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman leaves shot briefly (we HOLD on CHILDREN) She re-en and goes to them with a bowl of steaming potatoes. They t hands-ful, and make to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go 'way; go 'way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn away and walk towards boat. She looks after the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such times, when youngins run the  roads!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the SHOT. We frame them briefly, walking away, then;

dialogues.speaker: A PLACARD
dialogues.text: It is lit by firelight. It reads: PEACH-PICKERS WANTED WEEKLY HIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) An ungrateful child is an  abomination...

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER AND MEN
dialogues.text: PREACHER stands behind the flames; in FOREGROUND an OLD M sits profiled on a box. Other workers, all men, sit aroun fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...before the eyes of God. The world  is fast going to damnation because  of impudent youngins a-flyin' in the  face of Age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short silence, as the other men look at PREACHER without  liking. Then the old man spits into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLAMES
dialogues.text: A spurt of steam as spit strikes.

dialogues.speaker: A HOOT OWL
dialogues.text: ...hooting.

dialogues.speaker: A TURTLE
dialogues.text: He comes down to water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) They make soup out of them...

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN IN PASSING SKIFF
dialogues.text: Full landscape in BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...but I wouldn't know how to go  about gettin' him open.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN AND SKIFF, OVER RABBITS IN GRASS
dialogues.text: We shoot OVER two sitting rabbits as they watch, their ea up. The skiff passes. PEARL plays with doll JOHN unsnarls line.

dialogues.speaker: TWILIGHT
dialogues.text: The skiff passes. Baa-ing of sheep o.s.

dialogues.speaker: FROM RIVER
dialogues.text: The sheep bleats. We PAN in a big barn near the river, th a lighted house; willows along shore.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKIFF
dialogues.text: JOHN re-sets his oar. They angle towards us for the shore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna spend a night on land.

dialogues.speaker: UP-SHOT
dialogues.text: ...they reach top of the bank. Corner of barn and lighted window in BACKGROUND. Sounds of mouth-organ and girl sing o.s.

dialogues.speaker: A LIGHTED WINDOW, THE SHADE DRAWN
dialogues.text: A wire bird-cage hangs close to the shade, silhouetted. O the perch, a canary. Lullaby and mouth-organ continue o. After a moment the CHILDREN enter, backs to us, and stop, looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Window-light on faces, song over. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we goin' home, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, her hand in his. We PAN as they tiptoe towards big, open door of barn; big open hayloft window above.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: As they walk down aisle of barn we shoot them past bellie and legs of row of cows. Sounds of munching and soft lowi o.s. JOHN helps PEARL up a little ladder to the hayloft.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, WINDOW
dialogues.text: ...as the CHILDREN bed down in hay, only legs visible,  protruding into frame of window, which frames a middle-di white lane beyond house, and a landscape. Whippoorwill o. A DARKENING OF LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SET-UP
dialogues.text: The full moon is half-risen. Whippoorwill o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SET-UP
dialogues.text: The moon is well above the horizon. Whippoorwill o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SET-UP
dialogues.text: The moon is still higher. A pause; the whippoorwill stops mid-phrase. Brief pause; then John sits up into silhouett

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He listens intently. We hear nothing. His eyes alter. We  hear, distantly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., singing) Leaning, Leaning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At various distances o.s., we hear dogs barking at the so of the singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; louder) ...safe and secure from all alarms;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog from the farm rushes braying to his gate. Other d continue o.s. PREACHER appears, astride his walking horse singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Watching; dread and despair. Sounds go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Leaning; Leaning on the Everlasting  Arms.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He approaches and crosses center screen, continuing the h (We do not PAN with him; he crosses the frame of the grea window.)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Eyes following PREACHER. PREACHER and dogs continue o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Don't you never sleep?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He vanishes beyond trees, his singing more distant. Dogs  continue.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND PEARL
dialogues.text: He wakes her. PREACHER'S singing o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared whisper) Pearl, wake up! Come on, Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He vanishes; scuttling of children in hay, o.s.; dogs qui his song dies. Brief silence. The whippoorwill resumes.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, NEAR BARN
dialogues.text: Hand in hand, they hurry out of barn and, as we PAN, alon its side, towards River, o.s. Whippoorwill o.s.

dialogues.speaker: A BRIGHT FULL MOON
dialogues.text: The whippoorwill's singing continues o.s.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN AND SKIFF
dialogues.text: JOHN steers through turbulent, moonlit water. Whippoorwil continues. Low moon.

dialogues.speaker: ASLEEP IN SKIFF, (TANK)
dialogues.text: Blank, calm water; the skiff enters and passes full lengt below us, the CHILDREN asleep in it; blank water again; a the fox barks.

dialogues.speaker: GRASS
dialogues.text: Crickets o.s. The skiff nears a sand-bar.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROW, GROUNDING
dialogues.text: The prow softly grates against sand.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUNDED SKIFF, AGAIN THROUGH GRASS
dialogues.text: Crickets fainter. TILTING UPWARD.

dialogues.speaker: RIVER LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: Distant; medium; the near; roosters crow o.s.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAKING
dialogues.text: He looks to PEARL o.s.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL, THEN RACHEL, OVER JOHN
dialogues.text: PEARL is picking daisies. A fence up beyond her. Beyond t fence, a woman, RACHEL COOPER, appears. She carries a ber basket on her arm. JOHN scrambles up, grabs an oar, and h it defensively. PEARL freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) You two youngsters get up here to me  this instant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Mind me now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN lowers the oar at the female authority in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Now git on up to my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hesitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll git me a willow switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still hesitate. She breaks off a switch and comes fo them, squishing through the mud. She surrounds them and d them like geese up the bank.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE, FROM SIDE
dialogues.text: They move across the meadow like a nursery frieze. She tw with her switch. As she goes near PEARL'S calves, JOHN tu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you hurt her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurt her nothin'! Wash her's more  like it! (hand to mouth, yelling) Ruby!

dialogues.speaker: A TOMATO PATCH
dialogues.text: Three crouching figures pick tomatoes beyond a low white  fence; Rachel's house in background. RUBY, thirteen, pops her head up like a rifle-target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Clary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clary, eleven, pops up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, four, pops up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Yes Miz Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND HARPERS, MOVING TOWARDS FENCE
dialogues.text: She has JOHN and PEARL by their napes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring yer baskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three girls enter, their backs to us, carrying basket of tomatoes.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRLS, OVER RACHEL AND HARPER CHILDREN
dialogues.text: She holds JOHN and PEARL very firmly, inspecting baskets, across gate of fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicely picked, Clary. Mary; put the  big ones on top. Ruby, most o' them  ain't fit to go to market. Put them  baskets down. Ruby, fetch the washtub  and put it by the pump. Mary, Clary,  fetch me a bar o' laundry soap and  the scrub brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Yes Miz Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurry off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, now; up to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the gate, pushes the Harper children through, s the gate, and walks between them, her back to us. The chi hesitate. She turns to them and stops.

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: She looks them up and down. If we saw her face, her lips  would be pursed and working with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracious! If you hain't a sight to  beat all! Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer; their eyes are wide with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Speak up now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes go down to her feet. He, and we, start to examin her from foot to head; for this is our heroine at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...from JOHN'S eye-level. We TILT SLOWLY UP her height. S wears man's shoes, heavy with mud; a rough skirt; a shape sweater hangs over her shoulders; she is in her middle si and wears a man's old hat. Her face says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sort of roughly) Gracious! So I've got two more mouths  to feed!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: For no reason at all he feels he has come home.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, PEARL, RACHEL, RUBY, DURING WASHING
dialogues.text: RACHEL mercilessly scrubs JOHN; JOHN doesn't like it; RUB washes PEARL with a cloth.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hating the scrubbing. He breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND RACHEL
dialogues.text: JOHN dodges behind a bush, RACHEL in hot pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUSH
dialogues.text: RACHEL'S head bobs up and down above the bush; we hear th unmistakable sound of a female hand on a child's bottom.

dialogues.speaker: BROOD
dialogues.text: All carry baskets. RACHEL charges along at the head of th procession. A CATTLE DEALER strolls the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy Miz Cooper -- you goin' to  sell me yer hog this year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL doesn't stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the price o' pork what it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking to herself) I'm butcherin' my hog myself, smokin'  the hams, and cannin' the sausage. (she calls to children  over her shoulder) You-all have your work cut out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She talks to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Maw's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't our Maw. We just live at  her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Daddy's in Dee-troit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruby) Who's your folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS, wearing an apron labeled EMPIRE EATS, hurries across the street towards the GROUP. We PAN her in to MAR The procession halts briefly. She embraces MARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary! Honey! Mornin' Miz Cooper. (to Mary) Guess what! I'm savin' up to buy ye  a charm bracelet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the gewgaws; don't you  miss your visit this Sunday; and  come to Church with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITRESS hurries away. She dodges past a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ye Sunday, love!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: she follows WAITRESS, then LOVERS in car, with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car CENTERS, held up in traffic; two lovers in it, si close.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She takes in the LOVERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women is durn fools! All of 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sighs, angry at all women, herself included, and turn away. We are at the door of a GROCERY STORE. The GROCER i on his doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to children) Take yer baskets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHILDREN file in past her and GROCER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Grocer) Looky there. (she indicates the  lovers) She'll be losin' her mind to a tricky  mouth and a full moon, and like as  not I'll be saddled with the  consequences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts into store with the GROCER.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, GROCER, CHILDREN
dialogues.text: RACHEL and GROCER come up to counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; she takes  a list from her bosom  and gives it to Grocer) Here's what you owe me. (she counts baskets) One, two, three, four, five... where's  the other basket? Where's Ruby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John: you go fetch Ruby. (John goes. As Grocer  empties baskets and  tots up, Rachel  continues:) Big Ruby's my problem girl. She can't  gather eggs without bustin' 'em; but  Ruby's got mother hands with a  youngin, so what're you to say?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY
dialogues.text: She stands with her market-basket, reacting to wolf whist o.s.; she is seeking the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout tonight, Ruby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY gestures RACHEL'S nearness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to 1st) What gives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Lady's around. (to Ruby) How 'bout Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to 2nd) The old gal thinks she comes in fer  sewin' lessons o'-Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Miz Cooper wants you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes; RUBY, with an eye to 1ST LOAFER, turns and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pearl) And will you show me your dolly,  little lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN has entered in BACKGROUND. PEARL holds the doll to h and JOHN moves in quietly to her side. They stand togethe as so often before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ye got two more peeps to your  brood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and ornerier than the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your own boy, Miz Cooper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't heard from Ralph since last  Christmas. Don't matter -- I've got  a new crop. (she laughs. Loudly) I'm a strong tree with branches for  many birds. I'm good for something  in this old world and I know it,  too! We know that she will rout the  Devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a good tradesman) Got a good buy in soap, Miz Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphant) Don't need no soap. I'm boilin' down  the fat from my hog.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, GIRLS, JOHN ASIDE
dialogues.text: CENTERING RACHEL as she takes a book from table, and the  GIRLS MOVE to set at her seat, and JOHN stands to one sid RACHEL glances at him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He looks suspiciously to the Book in her hands, for to hi it has come to mean only Preacher.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIBLE
dialogues.text: ...as she opens it on her lap o.s. we hear a screen door  open.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, CHILDREN, JOHN IN BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: We see the door closing as JOHN goes out. The girls sit o low stools in semi-circle at RACHEL'S feet. We CENTER RAC RACHEL, keenly aware of JOHN, pretends to ignore him. JOH crosses behind her and stands with his back to us. We see the back of his head through the screen. RACHEL, changing her mind about what story to tell, finds the new page she after, and spreads her hands flat on the pages. She never glances at the text. She is fishing for JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now old Pharoah, he was the King of  Egyptland! And he had a daughter,  and once upon a time (louder) she was walkin' along the river bank  and she seen somethin' bumpin' and  scrapin' along down on a sandbar  under the willows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) And do you know what it was, children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still loud) Well, now, it was a skiff, washed up  on the bar. And who do you reckon  was in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidently) Pearl and John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still loud) Not this time! It was just one youngin --  a little boy babe. And do you know  who he was, children?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S HEAD
dialogues.text: ...as he turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in unison) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL closes the Bible; she knows the Lord's battle is w As she continues, she puts aside the book and takes up he mending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) It was Moses! -- A King of men, Moses,  children. Now. Off to bed. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On "off to bed," JOHN turns his back again.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She mends for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (commandingly) John, git me an apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN crosses behind her and off, towards door. We hear it open and close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git one for yourself, too.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He approaches with two apples. We PAN him into a:

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: He gives her an apple. She immediately takes a bite. He  doesn't bite his. She looks up at him from her apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) John, where's your folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plainly) Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead. (she nods with finality)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN starts to eat his apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where ye from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't figger ye rowed that skiff  from Parkersburg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN makes a move; he slowly and tenderly reaches out his hand and lays his fingers on her knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me that story again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our heroine would like to thank the Lord openly, but she  knows she must not show her feelings; she speaks gruffly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Story, honey? Why, what story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About them Kings. That the Queen  found down on the sandbar in the  skiff that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kings! Why, honey, there was only  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mind you said there was two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shoot! Maybe there was!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Maybe we see -- though JOHN does not -- the thanksgiving her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, come to think of it, there was  two, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., in distance, we hear the whistle of a river boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her head and shoulders from behind as she walks down the  neon-lighted street; drugstore and loafers in b.g.; jazz  music o.s.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY, OVER DRUGSTORE LOAFERS
dialogues.text: Our two loafers lounge on a bench. RUBY approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to 1st) Hey. Must be Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and starts towards RUBY, who catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to a magazine stand and fingers a magazine, awa LOAFER, who approaches in BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY'S HAND
dialogues.text: They are lurid, tawdry fan and pin-up magazines. PREACHER enters, between RUBY and LOAFER, and turns to RU into CLOSE TWO-SHOT. LOAFER pauses in BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Ruby, ain't you, my child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely. I'd like to talk to you, my  dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you buy me a choclit sody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O' course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out Preacher! Why, Preacher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) Shet yer dirty mouths!

dialogues.speaker: RUBY
dialogues.text: She looks up at him admiringly; then to LOAFERS; back to  PREACHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY is finishing her soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't I purty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a familiar clue to PREACHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you're the purtiest girl I've  seen in all my wandering. Didn't  nobody never tell you that, Ruby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) No. No one never did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving in) There's two new ones over at your  place, ain't there Ruby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's their names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl and John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh. (whispering) And is there -- a doll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Only she won't never let me play  with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and heads for door. RUBY, dismayed, hurries af him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides through door, RUBY following.

dialogues.speaker: B.G. 1ST LOAFER HAS GONE
dialogues.text: PREACHER comes out fast, RUBY touches his arm, he turns o her. They are in CLOSE TWO-SHOT. RUBY goes on tiptoe. PRE inclines his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever see such purty eyes in  all your born days?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER INSERT
dialogues.text: It slides into his knife pocket. We hear a click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Don't let him git away, Sugar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't like you-all! Next time I  won't even ask him to buy me a sody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to PREACHER, but PREACHER, on "next time," has  left the SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY
dialogues.text: She looks after him, clasping the magazine under her chin

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Her hero strides away into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY
dialogues.text: Gazing after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been bad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, you didn't have no money to  buy this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll whip me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did I ever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man down at the Drugstore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Drugstore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Cooper. I never went to sewin'  lessons all them times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been out with men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY collapses face down over RACHEL'S lap and sobs, as w TRACK IN CLOSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God, child!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now RACHEL also weeps. She bends low over RUBY, stroking hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You was lookin' for love, Ruby, the  only foolish way you knowed how. (she lifts Ruby's  face cheek to cheek  beside her own) We all need love. Ruby, I lost the  love of my son -- I've found it with  you-all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weep together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must grow up to be a fine, full  woman; and I'm goin' to see to it  you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts making up RUBY'S hair like that of a young wom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gentleman warn't like them! He  just give me a sody and the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never asked me for nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have wanted somethin', Ruby.  A man don't waste time on a girl  unless he gets something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you all talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl and John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Pearl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he their Pap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why hasn't he been to the house?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY
dialogues.text: Seeing PREACHER, she drops two eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Miz Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. from within  house) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man! The man!

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: He tethers his horse and, as we PAN and TRACK on behind h walks to the bottom of the steps; RUBY moves into side of SHOT: beyond PREACHER, RACHEL stands behind her screen do hands folded under apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin', ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'do.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: RACHEL'S VIEWPOINT, through screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Miz Cooper, I take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming through door) It's about that John and that Pearl?

dialogues.speaker: THREE-SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER'S face twitches with emotion. He breaks out into great thankful sobs. He falls to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little lambs! To think I never  hoped to see them again in this world!  Oh, dear Madam, if you was to know  what a thorny crown I have borne in  my search for these strayed chicks!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She takes him in. He doesn't take her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, go fetch them kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY minces off around the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He wipes off tears with the heel of his left hand, watchi her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, dear Madam, I see you're looking  at my hands!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She is.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He holds up the right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I tell ye the little story of  Right-Hand-Left-Hand -- the tale of  Good and Evil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) It was with this left hand that old  brother Cain struck the blow that  laid his brother low --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wanting to know) Them kids is yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering from the  interruption) My flesh and blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your Missus?

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She run off with a drummer one night.  Durin' prayer-meetin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's she at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewheres down river! Parkersburg,  mebbe! -- Cincinnati! -- One of them  Sodoms on the Ohio River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took them kids with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven only knows what unholy sights  and sounds those innocent little  babes has heard in the dens of  perdition where she dragged them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right funny, hain't it, how they  rowed all the way up river in a ten- foot john-boat!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: ...recovering, and by-passing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND PREACHER, FROM SIDE
dialogues.text: All the CHILDREN enter, around corner of house. As they m in, RACHEL replies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sight better than they was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now JOHN is on the top step beside RACHEL. One of his  hands holds on to her skirt, as if he were pulling her to him. His eyes never leave hers. All the CHILDREN freeze,  PEARL is on ground, just beyond JOHN. Others in BACKGROUN RUBY as near PREACHER as she can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracious, gracious! You are a good  woman, Miz Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you figgerin' to raise them two  without a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord will provide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL, with a wail of happiness, drops the DOLL on the st and runs to PREACHER, who picks her up. JOHN instantly pi up the DOLL and holds it to him. He looks up at RACHEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks deep into RACHEL'S eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) The Lord is merciful! What a day is  this! -- And there's little John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Come to me, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me, boy?

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: RACHEL bends a little over him. She wants the situation  clarified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, when your Dad says 'come', you  should mind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't my Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes this in; JOHN has sold her. She looks to PREACH o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't no Preacher neither. I've  seen Preachers in my time, an' some  of 'em was saints on earth. A few  was crookeder'n a dog's hind leg,  but this 'un's got 'em all beat for  badness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks purposefully into the house. PREACHER lunges fo JOHN and the DOLL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN ducks under the porch and PREACHER tries to follow h He can't get under. o.s. we hear the slam of the screen d PREACHER'S head comes up to see and we TILT UP, shooting  OVER the back of his head. RACHEL stands there, full figu with a pump-gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just march yourself yonder to your  horse, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back of PREACHER'S head is still immobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March, Mister! I'm not foolin'.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, OVER GUN-BARREL
dialogues.text: PREACHER gets to his feet. The open knife is in his hand. we see it, the gun-barrel twitches. PREACHER backs away  towards his horse, bouncing the knife lightly in his hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) You ain't done with Harry Powell  yet! The Lord God Jehovah will guide  my hand in vengeance! You devils!  You Whores of Babylon! I'll come  back when it's dark!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he mounts his horse we

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is dark. o.s. we hear PREACHER singing Leaning.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She sits in profile, her gun across her knees. Song conti o.s.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, ASLEEP
dialogues.text: ...in a big bed. RUBY sits up, listening to song o.s.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, AS BEFORE
dialogues.text: Song continues o.s. We PAN to PREACHER outside. We see hi through window. He sits hunched on a stump.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE, OVER PREACHER
dialogues.text: He continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD PROFILE
dialogues.text: After a moment we see her mouth open; and either to comfo herself or to drown out PREACHER'S voice, she joins in th hymn.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: A descending candle moves past a window; RACHEL and PREAC sing o.s.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER ON STUMP
dialogues.text: ...over back of RACHEL'S head. The song ends. RUBY enters SHOT carrying a candle. Its light blacks out the window-g RACHEL looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonin' around the house over that  mad dog of a Preacher! Shame, Ruby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blows out the candle. We see through the window. PREA has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merciful Heaven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, get the children out of bed.  Bring them all down here to the  kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY leaves the SHOT. RACHEL moves towards window. She pu her hand over her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women is such fools!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soft hoot of an owl o.s. RACHEL looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Still for a second; then o.s., the scream of a rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hard world for little things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER this line we have heard the patter of feet down  staircase. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: They look at her with complete trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) Children, I got lonesome. I figgered  we might play games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL and MARY jump up and down, patting their palms. RAC extends her hands and they gather close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you tell us a story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might (a swift furious glance  into the moonlight) I might tell a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down, the gun across her knees.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: ...as MARY and PEARL sit at her feet. RUBY stands beside  RACHEL. JOHN stands near RACHEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll light the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more fun hearin' stories in the  dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARY sits at RACHEL'S feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is alert now. He moves in close beside RACHEL, whom we PAN into CLOSE TWO-SHOT with him, and presses the whole o his right arm against her arm. RACHEL registers quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... mind what I told you about  little Jesus and his Ma and Pa and  how there was No Room at the Inn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes, sharp and glittering, look outside.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: She gets up with gun; we PULL AWAY; in BACKGROUND, CHILDR turn faces to keep watching her. She comes close to windo gun ready, CHILDREN in BACKGROUND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, there was this sneakin',  no-'count, ornery King Herod!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns round and walks back to her chair; CHILDREN'S e always on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he heard tell of this little  King Jesus growin' up and old Herod  figgered: Well, shoot! There sure  won't be no room for the both of us! (she sits down) I'll just nip this in the bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, he never knowed for sure which  one of all them babies of the land  was King Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes glittering as she turns to look towards us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL gets up, with gun. Again we PULL AWAY, as faces of all CHILDREN in b.g. turn to watch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so that cursed old King Herod  figgered if he was to kill all the  babies in the land, he'd be sure to  get little Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without speaking, she goes back to her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more relaxed) And when little King Jesus' Ma and  Pa heard about that plan, what do  you reckon they went and done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hid in a broom closet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hid under the porch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No; they went a-runnin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, John, that's just what  they done! They went a-runnin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock starts striking three. RACHEL looks to sound o.

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK AND HALL MIRROR, BEYOND DARK KITCHEN
dialogues.text: In the mirror, a shadow ducks.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: RACHEL gets up, gun at port, and faces into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Figured I was gone, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes on the darkness, she bends low to the CHILDREN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Run hide in the staircase! Run quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They scatter out of shot; RUBY lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning to  her) Ruby, git.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY obeys in a trance. RACHEL, gun at ready, looks into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; in a high,  steady voice) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Them kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) What are you after them for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) None of your business, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm givin' you to the count of three  to get out that screen door; then  I'm a-comin' across this kitchen  shootin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stepped-on cat screams o.s. and PREACHER'S satanic face and his hand lifting the open knife, rise swiftly from fl

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She fires off her gun.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN DOOR
dialogues.text: PREACHER staggers out and runs yelping with pain into the barn. o.s. we hear the zing-zing of a country phone being cranked.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, OVER BACKS OF CHILDREN'S HEADS
dialogues.text: They huddle on the stairs in reverent silence. RACHEL, he gun slung sportily under one arm, talks into wall phone w hangs just within the box stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Booher? Rachel Cooper. Git them  State Troopers out to my place. I  done treed somep'n up in my barn.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND JOHN
dialogues.text: RACHEL sits on the screened porch, awake, gun on knees. J sits on floor, asleep, his head leaning against her. Barn BACKGROUND. Sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND JOHN
dialogues.text: Same position. JOHN awakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see to Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get up and start into kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, OVER RACHEL AND JOHN
dialogues.text: They lie huddled in calm sleep. JOHN and RACHEL watch a  moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start for the stove.

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: RACHEL puts her gun beside the stove, ready to hand, and  picks up a coffee-pot; JOHN puts kindling in stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, you know? When you're little  you have more endurance than God is  ever to grant you again? Children  are Man at his strongest. They abide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks at her a moment. o.s. we hear police car siren They look towards the sound.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH POLICE CAR WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: We SHOOT OVER two TROOPERS. Sirens loud, they rapidly app RACHEL'S house as RACHEL, without gun, holding JOHN'S han comes down to fence. Presently, the other CHILDREN hurry of house behind. The car brakes.

dialogues.speaker: BARN IN BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: The TROOPERS, fanning wide, advance towards barn. RACHEL the CHILDREN are grouped a short distance behind them. Th barn door gapes black. Short pause; then PREACHER appears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Is that him, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Yes! Mind where you shoot, boys!  There's children here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't you call us up before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't want yer big feet trackin' up  my clean floors.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: He stands, swaying; his left arm is bloody and helpless. his right hand the open knife hangs apathetic. His eyes a glazed. He does not seem to care whether they come or not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Harry Powell, you're under arrest  for the murder of Willa Harper!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER AND TROOPERS
dialogues.text: TROOPERS close in on PREACHER, from before and behind, ex as for BEN'S arrest.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The same sickly look, as at BEN'S arrest.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER AND TROOPERS
dialogues.text: One TROOPER smacks the back of PREACHER'S head with a pis barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another TROOPER, with a pistol barrel, knocks the knife f PREACHER'S lifted hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREACHER sinks to his knees as both men, and two others f the front, close in on him. The tableau is the same as in BEN'S arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Dad!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: JOHN grabs the DOLL from PEARL and starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John! John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts after him.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPERS, JOHN, RACHEL, OVER PREACHER
dialogues.text: PREACHER prostrate along bottom of screen. TROOPERS are  beating him. JOHN runs up from BACKGROUND followed by RAC JOHN rushes among the TROOPERS, flogging PREACHER over th head with the DOLL. The TROOPERS, astounded, lay off. RAC is stopped in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here! Here! Take it back! I can't  stand it, Dad! It's too much, Dad! I  don't want it! I can't do it! Here!  Here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOLL has burst open and the money has spilled over  PREACHER. Now two TROOPERS gently lift JOHN away. RACHEL  lifts him in her arms; she turns towards house.

dialogues.speaker: BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: She carries JOHN towards the house. His head hangs back o her arm. We hear his dry, exhausted sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Lynch him! Lynch him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Bluebeard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling at all the  men around him) Twenty-five wives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he killed every last one of 'em!

dialogues.speaker: WALT, ICEY, MEMBERS OF COURTROOM AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Perhaps ten faces. Most are frenetic. Our two LOAFERS are having fun. General hubbub o.s. A gavel o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) If the People of Marshall County...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically, across  her) Bluebeard! Bluebeard!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He looks to sound of gavel. The hubbub and the gaveling s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Will you identify the prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks over his shoulder in same direction as the gav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Please, little lad. Won't you look  yonder... (his pointing finger  enters the shot.  John shakes as if he  had a cold) ...and tell the Court if that is the  man who killed your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks at the finger. Short pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) It's all right, Mrs. Cooper. You can  take the little fellow away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LAWYER'S hands gently help him from chair.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: ...as LAWYER'S hands consign JOHN to RACHEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas to you and yours,  Mrs. Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHILDREN bob and reply, ad lib, "Merry Christmas to y RACHEL sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) And what's Santy Claus going to bring  you, little man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above JOHN'S head, by winding and holding to ear, RACHEL  pantomimes a watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) O-ho-oo-o!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Them is the ones he sinned against,  my friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaveling starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Bluebeard! Bluebeard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Bluebeard! Bluebeard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As RACHEL and CHILDREN turn to go, gaveling and hubbub fa and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL and her CHILDREN sit in two booths, in a corner, n to a big front window. Christmas parcels on bench at RACH right.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND HER GROUP, THEN CAFE AND WINDOW
dialogues.text: Sound o.s. of approaching crowd. As we PULL BACK we bring a few other customers and the big window. There are Chris decorations in the cafe and the street outside is hung wi them. Thirty feverish people, some of whom carry torches, enter the scene; ICEY stares in the window and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high-pitched) Them's hers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the cafe stands up. RACHEL gathers her parcel ICEY rushes to door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them's her orphans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Ruby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICEY shouts into the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them poor little lambs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICEY turns to the street mob. RACHEL hurries her CHILDREN door. ICEY leaves door to yell at mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them's the ones he sinned against,  my friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across Icey) Go out the back way, Miz Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As RACHEL leaves SHOT, the CASHIER shuts and locks the do

dialogues.speaker: COMPANY EMERGING FROM DOOR
dialogues.text: MARY and CLARY come out first and start walking to our le RACHEL comes out and hurries off to our right, followed b JOHN, holding PEARL'S hand. We PAN to MARY and CLARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't we goin' to the Bus Depot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. They turn and we PAN with them as they hurry a RACHEL, and we bring in RACHEL, charging away from us wit her brood hustling to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING WALT AND ICEY
