dialogues.text: ICEY carries a torch. She is flanked by rabid faces and b smiling LOAFERS, one of whom carries an axe. As she speak a MAN rushes up to WALT and gives him a rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting; high-pitched) Draggin' the name of the Lord through  the evil mud of his soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all start marching, in step.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Marching and voices o.s. and in BACKGROUND. Carrying Christmas parcels, they hurry alongside a buildi and, at CENTER of PAN, cross the end of a street. The MOB marches down the street TOWARDS CAMERA; Men run t join it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high-pitched) He lied!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tricked us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taken the Lord's name in vain and  he trampled on His Holy Book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: String that Bluebeard up to a pole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Satan hiding behind the Cross!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Lynch him! String him up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN RACHEL and CHILDREN past this street and they hurr towards RUBY, who stands alone in BACKGROUND, facing the  jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In BACKGROUND, RACHEL and CHILDREN hurry towards her. MOB noise o.s. Hearing the approach of RACHEL'S GROUP, RUBY t the back of her head towards us. Now there are no mob voi only the ominous sound of fifty-odd people marching in st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him!

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Ominous silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loves me because I'm so purty!  You think he's like them others!

dialogues.speaker: RUBY, RACHEL AND GROUP
dialogues.text: Marching sound o.s. RACHEL firmly takes RUBY'S arm and drags her off in our  direction. RACHEL shoos MARY and CLARY ahead of her. JOHN and PEARL flank RACHEL, clinging to her wide skirts. RUBY nearest us, keeps looking back over her shoulder. We TRAC them along side of JAIL to rear of JAIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You took on something awful about  him buying me that there movie book.  You was so mad you shot him and the  blue men took him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On "blue men," we stop TRACKING and, as GROUP leaves SHOT CENTER a POLICE CAR, waiting at rear door of JAIL. POLICE start out of door.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMEN AND PREACHER
dialogues.text: They roughly hustle PREACHER into the car. Marching sound o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: PREACHER and POLICE are in b.g. Through car window we see BART the HANGMAN come out of his door. He wears his derby POLICEMAN puts head out of window. Marching sound o.s.

dialogues.speaker: BART THE HANGMAN
dialogues.text: On porch, by door, is a doll's perambulator, but this tim there is a Christmas wreath on the door. Marching o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Hey Bart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auto engine starts up o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Marching o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) We're savin' this bird up fer you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marching o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time it'll be a privilege.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR, THEN RACHEL AND GROUP
dialogues.text: The car jumps fast out of SHOT and we PAN PAST BART and C RACHEL and GROUP, walking fast away from us. Mob voices o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., over departing  car) Bust the door down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clutching Christmas parcels they hurry away from us into  darkness. RUBY, hanging back, dragged by RACHEL, babbles  over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) They'll git him out. I'll git my  things ready -- my shawl and my Mickey  Mouse wristwatch that don't run and  the straw hat with the flower, and  we'll be married and live happily  ever after!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. ad lib, cutting  across Ruby) Bust the door down! Set fahr to it!  Where's that axe! Climb up on the  balcony! You six git 'round to the  back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., screaming) People of Marshall County!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AT MAILBOX
dialogues.text: She peers into empty mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams the box shut and, as we TILT and PAN, walks awa from us through snow towards her lighted house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad they didn't send me nothing!  Whenever they do it's never nothing  I want but something to show me how  fancy and smart they've come up in  the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is decorated for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Rachel enters; the four girls stand in line, packages rea JOHN stands in b.g., in doorway to next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we give you your presents now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot! You don't mean to say you got  me a present!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their hands hold packages up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Why, Ruby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, JOHN leaves the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) A POT-HOLDER!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: From a fruit bowl, he selects the biggest apple, shines i on his shirt, wraps it in the doily under his bowl, opens drawer and gets out a clip clothespin, clips his package, and leaves shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., continuing) And much neater than last year's,  Ruby! (Sound of tearing  gift-paper o.s.) (o.s.) And Clary! ANOTHER POT-HOLDER! Ain't  that thoughtful. I'm always burnin'  my hands.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, AND CHILDREN, OVER JOHN
dialogues.text: ...as he enters with present. RUBY and CLARY are standing aside; MARY and PEARL hold up a third pot-holder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you two make this together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hop us, some.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, ACCEPTING JOHN'S GIFT
dialogues.text: She opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) John, that's the richest gift a body  could have. (continued, briskly) You'll find your presents in the  cupboard under the china-closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where, Ruby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All turn and run through door except Ruby, whom RACHEL  detains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby: (she takes a box from  her apron pocket) This is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUBY opens it quickly; it is a cheap costume-jewelry flow spray. RUBY and RACHEL kiss like grown women and RUBY goe to join the others.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She turns to her stove and is framed by Christmas garland b.g.; banging pots about and stirring; praying as she wor which is the best way to pray. Appropriate noise, o.s., of opening presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord save little children! (bang) You'd think the world would be ashamed  to name such a day as Christmas for  one of them... (bang) ...and go on the same old way. (she starts stirring) My soul is humble when I see the way  little ones accept their lot. (she pauses in stirring) Lord save little children! The wind  blows and the rain is cold. Yet,  they abide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In BACKGROUND, the girls run upstairs, their new dresses  over their arms. RACHEL glances over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: JOHN stands in next room, looking at something in his han

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We see he holds a watch. He looks like any boy, rich or p with his first watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering, so that  he does not hear) For every child, rich or poor there's  a time of running through a dark  place; and there's no word for a  child's fear. A child sees a shadow  on the wall, and sees a Tiger. And  the old ones say, "There's no tiger;  go to sleep." And when that child  sleeps, it's a Tiger's sleep, and a  Tiger's night, and a Tiger's breathing  on the windowpane. Lord save little  children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN enters boldly behind her and, with a scrape, masterf swings a chair around close to her and straddles it. RACH turns her back to us. She expects him to speak, he doesn' so she fills in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That watch sure is a fine, loud  ticker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN gives her a burning, proud smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be nice to have someone around  the house who can give me the right  time of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN finds his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This watch is the nicest watch I  ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feller can't just go around with  run-down, busted watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back, face to us, and goes on with her stirring JOHN goes off towards the staircase to join the girls; th turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't afraid no more! I got a watch  that ticks! I got a watch that shines  in the dark!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and hurries to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the sound of his running upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (telling us) They abide and they endure.
